title: STONE Score for Uncomplicated Ureteral Stone
desc: The STONE Score risk stratifies non-febrile ED patients to give a likelihood that their symptoms are being caused by a ureteral stone.

orgreference.text: Moore CL, Bomann S, Daniels B, et al. Derivation and validation of a clinical prediction rule for uncomplicated ureteral stone--the STONE score: retrospective and prospective observational cohort studies. BMJ. 2014;348:g2191.

other_refer.text: Choosing Wisely: Ten Things Physicians and Patients Should Question. American College of Emergency Physicians. October 27, 2014. Accessed October 23, 2018.

data.facts:
Interpretation:

STONE Score

Risk group

Risk of having ureteral stone

Note

0-5

Low risk

9.2%

Diagnostic decisions should be based on the other diagnoses being considered.

6-9

Moderate risk

51.3%

Ultrasound performed after hydration and demonstrating hydronephrosis would increase the likelihood that this patient's symptoms are being caused by a kidney stone, and may decrease the patient's cumulative radiation exposure.

10-13

High risk

88.6%

If clinically improving and low concern for alternative pathology, this patient could initially be managed conservatively without a CT scan. Low-dose CT would be appropriate if stone localization is needed.

Note: Within each group, higher score indicates higher likelihood of a stone.

inputs.name: pain

inputs.label_en: One or both ovaries are affected by a tumor that has either primary peritoneal cancer or pelvic extension, or below the pelvic brim.
inputs.name: hematuria

inputs.label_en: A tumor involving one or both ovaries may spread to the peritoneum outside the pelvis and/or metastasis to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes, as confirmed by histology or cytology testing.
